channel.title: NYT > Business
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: ‘Neoroyalism’ and What It Says About Trump
item.description: Experts are reaching to divine the president’s approach to global policy and economics, with one theory seeing antecedents in centuries-old dynastic rule.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman gave President Trump a warm and opulent welcome in Saudi Arabia last year.

item.title: Netflix Leader Pushes Warner Deal Before Skeptical Lawmakers
item.description: Senators asked Ted Sarandos about whether the acquisition would raise prices, squeeze talent and degrade the moviegoing experience.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ted Sarandos, left, a co-chief executive of Netflix, told a Senate subcommittee on Tuesday that “we’ll keep growing the American entertainment industry.”

item.title: Stephen Miran Resigns From White House as Fed Term Stretches On
item.description: Mr. Miran had taken a leave of absence from advising the president after adding a role at the Federal Reserve, drawing criticism from Democrats.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith and Tony Romm
item.category: White House Council of Economic Advisers
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stephen Miran, who is resigning as chair of the Council of Economic Advisers, can continue to serve as a Federal Reserve governor until a replacement is confirmed.

item.title: Grammy Awards Audience Declines by a Million Viewers
item.description: The show on Sunday drew about 14.4 million people. It is the second consecutive year that the awards ceremony attracted a smaller audience.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin
item.media:credit: Kevin Winter/Getty Images for The Recording Academy
item.media:description: Bruno Mars performing at the Grammy Awards on Sunday. As recently as 2024, the show had nearly 17 million viewers.

item.title: Meat Processors Take a Hit as Cattle Prices Remain High
item.description: Tyson Foods said its beef business could lose up to $500 million this year as the supply of cattle reaches a 75-year low.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Draper
item.media:description: Tyson Foods is among the companies struggling with the cost of beef, as the U.S. cattle supply remains at its lowest level since 1951.

item.title: Virginia Oliver, Maine’s ‘Lobster Lady’ and Folk Hero, Dies at 105
item.description: She fished off the New England coast for more than 80 years, and intended to continue until she died. “It’s not hard work for me,” she said at 101.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald
item.media:description: Ms. Oliver in 2021, when she was 101. “She represented that no-nonsense Mainer who just got up every day and did what they had to do,” said Barbara Walsh, the author of a children’s book about Mrs. Oliver.

item.title: Walmart Joins Tech Giants With $1 Trillion Market Valuation
item.description: The company’s rapid e-commerce growth and push into automation and artificial intelligence propelled its stock into the trillion-dollar club.
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone

item.title: The Questionable Science Behind the Odd-Looking Football Helmets
item.description: The N.F.L. claims Guardian Caps reduce the risk of concussions. The company that makes them says, “It has nothing to do with concussions.”
item.dc:creator: Ken Belson
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Guardian Sports, the company that makes Guardian Caps, says more than half a million athletes at all levels now wear the helmet enhancements.

item.title: ‘Don Colossus,’ a Golden Statue of President Trump, Waits for Its Home
item.description: A group of cryptocurrency investors backing a memecoin hopes the statue will soon be installed at one of Mr. Trump’s golf courses in Florida.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times

item.title: Jeffrey Epstein’s Trust Reveals Beneficiaries of His Fortune
item.description: Jeffrey Epstein wanted most of his money to go to his girlfriend. Mr. Epstein’s brother and a Harvard math professor were also named beneficiaries.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein
item.media:description: It’s unclear how much any of the beneficiaries to Jeffrey Epstein’s estate will receive. Its value has dropped significantly since his death, owing to payment of taxes, legal fees and settlements to victims of his sexual abuse.

item.title: Christy Tanner Named C.E.O. of New York Public Radio
item.description: Ms. Tanner was previously an executive at CBS News and serves on the board of Audacy, a major U.S. broadcaster and podcast producer.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Katie Jones/Variety, via Penske Media, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Christy Tanner, the next chief executive of New York Public Radio.

item.title: After Years of Increases, PepsiCo Pledges to Cut Prices on Snacks
item.description: The food and beverage giant said consumers were facing “affordability limitations.”
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell
item.media:description: PepsiCo said it had “begun offering greater affordability on certain packages of iconic brands,” including Doritos and Cheetos.

item.title: Disney Names Josh D’Amaro as Next C.E.O.
item.description: Mr. D’Amaro, 54, has most recently served as chairman of Disney Experiences, a division that includes theme parks, cruise vacations and consumer products.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Josh D’Amaro was named Disney’s next chief executive.

item.title: The Numbers, and Questions, Behind Musk’s Mega-Merger
item.description: The combination of SpaceX and xAI will create a rocket-and-A.I. giant. But investors and experts have concerns about the consequences of the deal.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Ian Mount
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: SpaceX is now a rocket-launching giant, a dominant force in satellite internet, a money-burning artificial intelligence business and a popular but divisive social media company.

item.title: Police Search X’s Premises in France as Prosecutors Summon Elon Musk
item.description: The move followed a yearlong investigation into X and escalated a wider standoff between European officials and American tech companies over the regulation of social media.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:description: Elon Musk in Davos, Switzerland, in January.

item.title: Investigation Finds Credit Suisse Had Wider Nazi Ties Than Previously Known
item.description: But a lawyer who has been scrutinizing archives and UBS are in a dispute over access to about 150 documents.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:description: “Shining light on Credit Suisse’s past is part of turning the page, a very dark chapter of history,” said Senator Charles E. Grassley, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee.

item.title: Siemens Energy Bets $1 Billion That A.I. Power Demand Will Last
item.description: The German manufacturer announced plans to expand factories in several U.S. states and build a new plant in Mississippi.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:description: A Siemens Energy factory in Berlin in 2017. The company is one of the world’s biggest manufacturers of gas turbines.

item.title: In Trump’s Fraud Crackdown, Political Foes Face Harshest Scrutiny
item.description: State officials say the president’s actions are a new form of retribution, even as the White House has pardoned allies charged with defrauding government.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: The president claims that his goal is to save taxpayers money, but some state officials say his actions are politically motivated and legally dubious.

item.title: The Global Economy’s Warning Signals Are Broken
item.description: From markets to spending to debt, usually reliable indicators that forecast where the economy is headed are proving deeply fallible.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen

item.title: Revisiting a Changed Maui, Nearly 3 Years After a Firestorm
item.description: As the town of Lahaina continues to rebuild, residents, local officials and even visitors are envisioning how tourism and community life can coexist in a new, more sustainable way.
item.dc:creator: Claire Fahy and Philip Cheung
item.media:description: Andrew Nakihei, of the HI Surf Club in the Maui town of Lahaina, takes his daughter out for a surfing lesson.

item.title: Trump and India Call Off Their Trade War, but the Terms of Peace Are Murky
item.description: Officials and business leaders welcomed lower tariffs, but India has not yet confirmed that it would stop buying Russian oil, which President Trump said Prime Minister Narendra Modi had agreed to.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India visited the White House last February, before bilateral relations between the countries decayed.

item.title: Waymo Raises $16 Billion to Fuel Global Ambitions
item.description: The self-driving car company, an arm of Google’s parent company, is rapidly expanding its service beyond a handful of cities.
item.dc:creator: Natallie Rocha
item.media:credit: Caitlin O'Hara for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waymo, Alphabet’s driverless car outfit, said it was now valued at $126 billion.

item.title: Brad Karp Says He Regrets Interactions with Epstein
item.description: Newly released emails between Mr. Karp, the chairman of Paul Weiss, and Jeffrey Epstein reveal a number of social interactions between them.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt and Matthew Goldstein
item.media:credit: Carly Zavala for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brad Karp, above, became acquainted with Jeffrey Epstein largely through his legal work for Leon Black, a co-founder of Apollo Global Management.

item.title: Elon Musk Merges SpaceX With His A.I. Start-Up xAI
item.description: The deal further intermingles Mr. Musk’s companies and creates the most valuable private company on earth.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac, Kate Conger, Maureen Farrell and Rob Copeland
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: SpaceX’s rocket facility in Boca Chica, Texas.

item.title: Trump Unveils $12 Billion Critical Minerals Stockpile
item.description: The “Project Vault” initiative is intended to reduce U.S. reliance on China for key technology components.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Tony Romm
item.media:description: A rare earth mine in Mountain Pass, Calif. The United States is working to develop its own supply chain for critical minerals.

item.title: Trump Would Have Slim Chance in Court Against Trevor Noah, Experts Say
item.description: Legal experts said that jokes like the one told by Mr. Noah at the Grammys on Sunday were protected by the First Amendment.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin
item.media:description: Trevor Noah speaks onstage during the 68th Grammy Awards on Sunday night.

item.title: Trump Announces Initial Trade Deal With India, Cutting Tariffs to 18%
item.description: The agreement was short on details, but President Trump said India had promised to stop buying Russian oil and would buy more U.S. farm goods and other products.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green, Tony Romm and Ana Swanson
item.media:description: President Trump and India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, were spare on details in their announcements, and Mr. Modi did not mention whether his country would stop buying Russian oil, as Mr. Trump claimed.

item.title: Jobs Report Delayed Because of Partial Shutdown
item.description: The report, scheduled for Friday, would have provided data on job growth, unemployment and wages in January.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Monthly jobs data released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics will be delayed because of a lapse in government funding.

item.title: France Adopts a Budget After Months of Turmoil
item.description: Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu’s budget, subjected to judicial review, paves the way for relative political stability.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:description: Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu of France, center in blue suit, at the National Assembly on Monday. The budget’s passage is expected to allow for a semblance of political stability after months of turmoil.

item.title: Minnesota Economy Suffers as I.C.E. Cracks Down
item.description: Immigration raids have scared off customers and workers, a pattern repeated in other cities where federal officials have arrived in force.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis
item.media:credit: Yasmin Yassin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Business is down in stores and restaurants around the Twin Cities, including at El Guanaco, a restaurant and bakery with several locations in the area.

item.title: The Major Business Names in the Epstein Files
item.description: Documents referencing prominent executives like Elon Musk, Howard Lutnick and Bill Gates underscored the wide web of boldfaced names tied to Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Ian Mount
item.media:description: Emails in Friday’s release of documents related to Jeffrey Epstein include correspondence involving Elon Musk and other notable business figures.

item.title: Stephen Ross and Ken Griffin Think Florida Is the Future for Business
item.description: Stephen Ross, the real estate developer, and Ken Griffin, the billionaire financier, are trying to attract businesses to their new base, South Florida.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:description: Stephen Ross has given millions — including to help develop a university campus and a hospital — to make South Florida more attractive to companies.

item.title: Disney’s Profit Wilts, Despite Streaming and Parks Growth
item.description: Per-share quarterly profit declined 7 percent from a year earlier, with difficulties in movies and TV offsetting robust Disney+ and theme park results.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.media:credit: Todd Anderson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Attendance at Disney’s theme parks in the United States increased 1 percent, while spending per visitor rose 4 percent.

item.title: Snow Drought, Political Shifts and Strikes Batter Ski Industry in Western U.S.
item.description: Little snowpack, strikes by mountain staff and Trump administration policies that are keeping international visitors away have made this a difficult season in the Rockies and beyond.
item.dc:creator: David Goodman
item.media:credit: William Woody for The New York Times
item.media:description: Telluride, in western Colorado, closed for nearly two weeks this winter because of a strike by its ski patrollers. The ski area, shown in a photo from Dec. 27, has also been hurt by a lack of snow.

item.title: Will the Spirit of 1976 Come to 2026?
item.description: Bicentennial celebrations across America were spirited and joyous. As the semiquincentennial approaches, there’s a different mood.
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz
item.media:description: Buster Smith, in Revolutionary garb, took part in an anti-big-business protest held by the People’s Bicentennial Commission at the Washington Monument on July 4, 1976.

item.title: The New Key to Restaurant Success? A Simple but Clever Model.
item.description: Novel approaches to the all-day cafe are working for diners and creative chefs across the country.
item.dc:creator: Brett Anderson
item.category: Pine & Crane DTLA (Los Angeles, Calif, Restaurant)
item.media:credit: Adam Amengual for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Dutchess, in Ojai, Calif., begins the day as a French bakery and turns into a Burmese restaurant at night.

item.title: The Effects of Tariffs, One Year Into Trump’s Trade Experiment
item.description: Five charts show the impact on the economy after a year of sweeping trade changes by the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: The Key to Managing Tariffs: Be Big and Have the President’s Ear
item.description: Several large American manufacturers are thriving despite the threat of higher costs. Smaller ones are struggling.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman
item.media:description: Boeing’s chief executive, Kelly Ortberg, left, with President Trump during a visit to Qatar in May.

item.title: Who Loves Turbulence, Airplane Food and the Middle Seat? They Do.
item.description: What the travelers who adore some common annoyances of flying can teach everyone else about the power of changing one’s perspective.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Nazaryan

item.title: Move Fast, but Obey the Rules: China’s Vision for Dominating A.I.
item.description: Beijing wants to lead the world in developing cutting-edge artificial intelligence, but it also wants companies to adhere to an increasingly complex set of rules.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin and Xinyun Wu
item.media:description: Executives at Zhipu AI, one of China’s most promising A.I. start-ups, alongside others, at a launch event at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange last month.

item.title: Squeezed Between Trump and China, India Looks for Faraway Friendships
item.description: India is overcoming its aversion to free-trade deals to cozy up with Canada and other middle powers.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India, center, met with Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, and António Costa, the president of the European Council, in New Delhi in January.

item.title: How Trump Appears in the Epstein Files
item.description: The New York Times found more than 5,300 files with references to Mr. Trump and related terms. They include salacious and unverified claims, as well as documents that had already been made public.
item.dc:creator: Steve Eder, Michael C. Bender and David Enrich
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Donald Trump in the Oval Office on Friday.

item.title: U.A.E. Firm Quietly Took Stake in the Trump Family’s Crypto Company
item.description: The $500 million agreement raises new concerns about the propriety of the president negotiating foreign policy with his own business partners.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Eric Lipton
item.media:credit: Katarina Premfors for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zach Witkoff, left, and Eric Trump, speaking in Dubai in May. Eric Trump signed an agreement with an Emirati-backed investment firm days before his father’s inauguration in January 2025.

item.title: Indonesia Lifts Ban on Grok After New Assurances From X Corp
item.description: Indonesia joined Malaysia and the Philippines in reversing its restrictions, weeks after it blocked the chatbot because it was used to generate sexually explicit images of real people.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: In this photo illustration, the Grok Imagine web page, which produces A.I.-generated images and video, is displayed on a computer screen.

item.title: Target’s New C.E.O. Faces Hometown Crisis as He Begins Turnaround Effort
item.description: Michael Fiddelke takes the top job at the struggling retailer amid continued unrest in the Twin Cities. A new boss also steps in at Walmart, where things are quieter.
item.dc:creator: Kim Bhasin
item.media:description: As he prepared to take the top job at Target, Michael Fiddelke acknowledged that the company was in a tough situation.

item.title: Snow Drought in the West Reaches Record Levels
item.description: Warm temperatures and extremely low snowfall threaten water resources for the year.
item.dc:creator: Jim Robbins

item.title: Nestlé’s Chief Is in Turnaround Mode. He Drinks 8 Cups of Coffee a Day.
item.description: Philipp Navratil recently took over the 160-year-old Swiss food giant, charged with reviving growth and regaining trust after his predecessor was ousted over a scandal.
item.dc:creator: Jordyn Holman
item.media:credit: Clara Watt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Philipp Navratil took the top job at Nestlé in September, becoming its third chief executive in a less than two years.

item.title: Did A.I. Take Your Job? Or Was Your Employer ‘A.I.-Washing’?
item.description: As companies blame artificial intelligence for layoffs, skeptics wonder whether that explanation captures the full picture.
item.dc:creator: Lora Kelley

item.title: ‘I’m Free’: A Muslim Official Who Lost Faith in China Gains a Voice
item.description: Ma Ruilin worked as a Communist Party cadre helping fellow Muslims navigate their country as religious minorities, until the official hostility became too great to bear.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:credit: Owen Davies for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ma Ruilin praying in the basement of a halal restaurant where he works in Manhattan.

item.title: ‘Melania’ Arrives With Strong Box Office Showing for a Documentary
item.description: Amazon backed up the Brink’s trucks for the vanity film, resulting in weekend ticket sales of about $7 million in North America, enough for third place.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.media:description: The first lady, Melania Trump, at a screening of “Melania” at the Kennedy Center in Washington on Thursday.
